front.p: “And God saw everything that He had made, and behold it was very good.”–GEN i, 31. GEN i, 31. A quotation from the Book of Genesis, the first book of the Bible, which describes God’s response after creating the world in six days.

lg.l: Tell me not, tell me not that the angel of woe Angel of woe. A reference to the Book of Revelation, the last book of the Bible, which describes an angel “flying through the midst of heaven, saying with a loud voice, Woe, woe, woe, to the inhabiters of the earth” (8:13).
Broods over the earth, in its throb or its glow,
Or that life’s a warfare with devilish foe;
Or that ‘tis a desert for body and soul,
A weary endurance of sorrow and dole,

A wilderness journey to heaven’s bright goal. Wilderness journey … heaven’s bright goal. The lines of this stanza evoke a Protestant view of the world, possibly drawing on the allegory of the journey made by Christian in John Bunyan’s The Pilgrim’s Progress (1678).
For I know, yes, I know that the earth it is fair;
And, though life is mixed up with sorrow and care,
It yet hath its sunshine, and flowers bloom there.
Our Creator is good, and His goodness is shown
In all the bright things that o’er earth he hath strown,

Though man, His creation, hath dimmed its bright tone. Man … bright tone. A reference to the original sin that marred the creation, described in Genesis 3, and possibly also to the environmental damage caused by settlers in Australia and New Zealand.
Let us look, let us look at the flowers on the lea,
At the insects at play, at the birds on the tree,
How fair, and how bright, and how happy they be!
And can we suppose the existence of man
Alone is created as under a ban;
And that, too, by God’s own deliberate plan?
No it’s not, no it’s not—earth is pleasant and bright
To all, save to those who, in self-induced night,
Choose to sit far from even a glimmer of light.
Things bright and things beautiful round us abound;
Kind hearts and warm friendships by seekers are found;
And foretastes of heaven are lying around.
Then say not, O say not that our portion is woe
While through our drear lifetime existence we go;
O mortals, how can you dishonour God so?
He hath made this earth bright, that a type Type. Invokes the typological interpretation of the Bible, which regards aspects of the Old Testament as symbols of the New Testament. we may see,
A shadowy type, of what heaven will be
When no more is the earth and no more is the sea.

body.p: ALFRED SHARPE, Newcastle. Newcastle. Sharpe had lived in New Zealand since 1859, but moved to Newcastle, New South Wales, in late 1887.
